0: Two active-duty Marines are under investigation in connection to a social media post purportedly threatening to attack gay bars following Sunday's deadly mass shooting in Florida. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The California-based I Marine Expeditionary Force launched a command investigation after a photo surfaced on social media showing a corporal in uniform holding a rifle with his finger near the trigger. The words “Coming to a gay bar near you!” appear at the bottom of the photo. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The picture was posted recently to Camp MENdleton resale, a closed Facebook group for male Marines with more than 25,000 members. The person who purportedly posted it also wrote “Too soon?” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The post follows Sunday's terror attack on a gay nightclub in Orlando, Florida, that killed 49 people and left 53 wounded. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR First Lt. Thomas Gray, a spokesman for I MEF, told Marine Corps Times that the command has identified the Marine in the picture and the one who posted it on Facebook. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “We cannot discuss details of an ongoing investigation, but I can tell you the command is taking this incident seriously,” Gray said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Marine officials have vowed to take “appropriate action” in response to the social media post, according to a statement released by I MEF. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "The Marine Corps does not tolerate discrimination based on sexual orientation, race, gender or religion," the statement says. “...This type of behavior and mindset will not be allowed, and it is not consistent with the core values of honor, courage and commitment that are demonstrated by the vast majority of Marines on a daily basis." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Michael Moss, the founder of the Camp MENdleton resale Facebook group, said on Facebook that the post was deleted as soon as it was reported, and the person was banned from the group immediately. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "We do not tolerate hate speech,” he said. Moss was not immediately available for comment. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The incident coincides with a separate investigation by the FBI and San Diego police into an anonymous threat posted Tuesday on the men-seeking-men section of the Craigslist San Diego personal ads, according to local television station KGTV. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Orlando was long overdue," the post stated, according to ABC affiliate. "...San Diego you are next."
